Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Diversification of the Self-incompatibility Locus in the Papaveraceae
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many plants can recognize and reject their own pollen in order to avoid the deleterious effects of self-fertilization. Current knowledge of pollen recognition systems in plants comes from just two molecular systems. This project will explore a third system, that of the poppy family. This system has several advantages for studying self-recognition including ease of mating-type determination and the availability of in-vitro assays of rejection reactions. The investigators will determine the history of different mating-type alleles at the self-recognition locus. The data will be used to test recent models of the development of self-recognition loci and will provide comparisons with other systems in which the selective forces are the same, but the molecular mechanisms of self-recognition differ.

Self-recognition genes provide stunning examples of extreme genetic variation. The process underlying this variation is selection that continuously favors new or rare types. Selection favoring rarity underlies the diversification of the immune system genes in humans and may be responsible for the maintenance of sex in plants and animals. This study will contribute to our knowledge of the maintenance of variation at these loci which is required to maintain population viability. In addition, this project will provide extensive training for undergraduate and graduate student, including Native Alaskans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We studied the evolutionary history of the locus controlling the ability of plants in the Papaveraceae (poppy family) to recognize and reject their own pollen, preventing self-fertilization. By enforcing outcrossing, self-incompatibilty loci increase the genetic diversity found in offspring and in populations. Because the mating system has a major impact on the partitioning of genetic variation within and among individuals and populations, genes that control the mating system can affect the longevity and diversification of species and lineages. 

We sequenced 87 alleles from the self-incompatibility locus of 5 species from four genera of Papaveraceae. These alleles generally explain mating compatibilities in crosses among siblings. Surprisingly, alleles at the self-incompatibility locus in the poppy family generally do not appear to be as old as those found in other incompatibility systems studied in flowering plants, perhaps due to the unique molecular basis of incompatibility in this family. We also found that across the wide diversity of flower morphologies exhibited within this family, self-pollen is always arrested immediately after contacting living female tissue.

Ancillary projects demonstrated: 1) that self-incompatibility increases the diversification rate of lineages, not by increasing speciation, but by decreasing extinction. 2) That the unique properties of the self incompatibility locus could be used to date a population bottleneck that occured earlier than the origin of extant species. 3) That the putative male component of a self-incompatibility system has either been incorrectly identified or is evolving by a mechanism unlike that of the female component (the latter has since been proven true).

This project supported one Ph.D. and one Master's student and research by several undergraduates. Outcomes have been disseminated through scientific meeting and publications.
